Vega API Reference¶

The full Vega specification is exposed through a set of object-relational JSON classes. Vincent also pr

Visualization¶

Field properties for Visualization:

name

string : Name of the visualization (optional)

width

int : Width of the visualization in pixels

Default is 500 if undefined.

height

int : Height of the visualization in pixels

Default is 500 if undefined.

viewport

2-element list of ints : Dimensions of the viewport

The viewport is a bounding box containing the visualization. If the dimensions of the visualization are larger than the viewport, then the visualization will be scrollable.

If undefined, then the full visualization is shown.

padding

int or dict : Padding around visualization

The padding defines the distance between the edge of the visualization canvas to the visualization box. It does not count as part of the visualization width/height. Values cannot be negative.

If a dict, padding must have all keys ''top', 'left', 'right', and 'bottom' with int values.

data

list or KeyedList of Data : Data definitions

This defines the data being visualized. See the Data class for details.

scales

list or KeyedList of Scale : Scale definitions

Scales map the data from the domain of the data to some visualization space (such as an x-axis). See the Scale class for details.

axes

list or KeyedList of Axis : Axis definitions

Axes define the locations of the data being mapped by the scales. See the Axis class for details.

marks

list or KeyedList of Mark : Mark definitions

Marks are the visual objects (such as lines, bars, etc.) that represent the data in the visualization space. See the Mark class for details.

legends

list or KeyedList of Legends : Legend definitions

Legends visualize scales, and take one or more scales as their input. They can be customized via a LegendProperty object.

Data¶

Field properties for Data:

name

string : Name of the data

This is used by other components (Mark, etc.) for reference.

url

string : URL from which to load the data

This can be used as an alternative to defining the data in the values attribute.

values

list : Data contents

Data is represented in tabular form, where each element of values corresponds to a row of data. Each row of data is represented by a dict or a raw number. The keys of the dict are columns and the values are individual data points. The keys of the dicts must be strings for the data to correctly serialize to JSON.

The data will often have an “index” column representing the independent variable, with the remaining columns representing the dependent variables, though this is not required. The Data class itself, however, is agnostic to which columns are dependent and independent.

For example, the values attribute [{'x': 0, 'y': 3.2}, {'x': 1, 'y': 1.3}] could represent two rows of two variables - possibly an independent variable 'x' and a dependent variable 'y'. For simple data sets, an alternative values attribute could be a simple list of numbers such as [2, 12, 3, 5].

It may be more convenient to load data from pandas or NumPy objects. See the methods Data.from_pandas() and Data.from_numpy().

source

string : name field of another data set

This is typically used with data transforms to create new data values.

transform

list : transforms to apply to the data

Note: Transform-relational classes are not yet implemented.

format

dict : information about the data format

This is only used when loading data from the url attribute. Format-relational classes are not yet implemented.

Scale¶

Field properties for Scale:

name

string : Unique name for the scale

This is used for referencing by other components (mainly Mark).

type

string : Type of the scale

Valid types are as follows:

  • 'ordinal': ordinal scale types
  • 'time' or 'utc': time scale types
  • 'linear', 'log', 'pow', 'sqrt', 'quantile', 'quantize', and 'threshold': quantitative scale types

For time scales, the value should be a Javascript-style numeric value of seconds. 'time' implies the value is in local time.

If unspecified, then the scale is assumed to be linear. See the d3 documentation for scale type details.

domain

list or DataRef : Domain of the scale

domain_min

float, int, or DataRef : Minimum domain value

Only used for quantitative/time scales. This takes precedence over the minimum of the domain property.

domain_max

float, int, or DataRef : Maximum domain value

Only used for quantitative/time scales. This takes precedence over the maximum of the domain property.

range

list or string : Range of the scale

For quantitative scales, the range may be specified as a two-element list of min/max values. For ordinal scales, the range should be a list of output values mapped to the input values.

String values may be used to automatically set a range:
  • 'width' - Set the range to the width of the visualization
  • 'height' - Set the range to the height of the visualization
  • 'shapes' - Equivalent to the symbol types ['circle', 'cross', 'diamond', 'square', 'triangle-down', 'triangle-up']
  • 'category10' - A pre-determined 10-color pallet
  • 'category20' - A pre-determined 20-color pallet
range_min

float, int, or DataRef : Minimum range value

Only used for quantitative/time scales. This takes precedence over the minimum of the range property.

range_max

float, int, or DataRef : Maximum range value

Only used for quantitative/time scales. This takes precedence over the maximum of the range property.

reverse

boolean : If True, flip the scale range

round

boolean : If True, numeric output values are rounded to integers

points

boolean : If True, distribute ordinal values over evenly spaced points between range_min and range_max

Ignored for non-ordinal scales.

clamp

boolean : If True, values that exceed the domain are clamped to within the domain

Ignored for ordinal scales.

nice

boolean or string : scale the domain to a more human-friendly set

If the scale type is 'time' or 'utc', then the value should be one of 'second', 'minute', 'hour', 'day', 'week', 'month', or 'year'.

If the scale type is a quantitative scale, then the value should be a boolean. The input values are rounded to a more human-friendly value. The details of the rounding are in the d3 documentation.

Ignored for ordinal scales.

exponent

float or int : Exponent for 'pow' scale types

Ignored for all scale types other than 'pow'.

zero

boolean : If True, include zero in the domain

Only valid for quantitative scale types. This is useful if the domain is defined as a DataRef that may not include 0 exactly.

padding

string: Ordinal element padding

Only valid for ordinal scale types

DataRef¶

Field properties for DataRef:

data

string : Name of data-set containing the domain values

field

string or list of strings : Reference to desired data field(s)

If multiple fields are given, then the values of all fields are included in the domain.

ValueRef¶

Field properties for ValueRef:

value

int, float, or string : used for constant values

This is ignored if the field property is defined.

field

string : reference to a field of the data in dot-notation

The data is taken from the Mark’s from_ property. For instance, if the data has a definition [{'x': 2}, {'x': 3}, {'x': 1}] then the data should be referenced as data.x. Note that the first element is always data regardless of the name of the data.

scale

string : reference to the name of a Scale

The scale is applied to the value and field attributes.

mult

int or float : multiplier applied to the data after any scaling

offset

int or float : additive offset applied to the data after any scaling and multipliers

band

boolean : use the range of the scale if applicable

If this is True and scale is defined, then the value referenced is the range band referenced scale. See the d3 documentation on ordinal.rangeBand for more info.

Mark¶

Field properties for Mark:

name

string : Optional unique name for mark

description

string : Optional description for mark

type

string : Type of mark

Valid types are 'rect', 'symbol', 'path', 'arc', 'area', 'line', 'image', and 'text'.

from_

dict : Description of data to visualize

Note that although the property has the name from_ (using from is invalid Python syntax), the JSON will contain the correct property from.

properties

MarkProperties : Mark property set definitions

key

string : Field to use for data binding

When updating data dynamically, restrict dynamic transitions from affecting data with the given key. This can be useful for something like scrolling time series. See the Vega examples.

delay

ValueRef, number : Transitional delay in milliseconds.

ease

string : Type of transition easing

Valid types are 'linear', 'quad', 'cubic', 'sin', 'exp', 'circle', and 'bounce', which can be appended with the modifiers 'in', 'out', 'in-out', and 'out-in'. The default is 'cubic-in-out'.

See the documentation for the d3 ease function for more details.

Mark Properties¶

Field properties for MarkProperties:

enter

PropertySet : properties applied when data is loaded

exit

PropertySet : properties applied when data is removed

update

PropertySet : properties applied for all non-exiting data

(This is vague. Need better Vega docs.)

hover

PropertySet, properties applied on mouse-over

On mouse out, the update properties are applied.

PropertySet¶

Field properties for PropertySet:

x

ValueRef : number, left-most x-coordinate

For most marks, this will be equal to the field of the independent variable. For example, {"scale": "x", "field": "data.x"} will place a mark with its left-most coordinate at the x-values of the data. Something like {"scale": "x", "value": 10} will place a single mark at given x-coordinate.

x2

ValueRef : number, right-most x-coordinate

Generally, for marks where the width is significant, it’s better to use the width property.

width

ValueRef : number, width of the mark

Set the band property of the ValueRef to True to use the full width.

y

ValueRef : number, top-most y-coordinate

The same remarks for the x property apply here.

y2

ValueRef : number, bottom-most y-coordinate

The same remarks for the x2 property apply here.

height

ValueRef : number, height of the mark

opacity

ValueRef : number, overall opacity (0 to 1)

fill

ValueRef : string, fill color for the mark

Colors can be specified in standard HTML hex notation or as CSS3 compatible strings. The color string is not validated due to its large number of valid values.

fill_opacity

ValueRef : int or float, opacity of the fill (0 to 1)

stroke

ValueRef : color, stroke color for the mark

Colors can be specified in standard HTML hex notation or as CSS3 compatible strings. The color string is not validated due to its large number of valid values.

stroke_width

ValueRef : int, width of the stroke in pixels

stroke_opacity

ValueRef : number, opacity of the stroke (0 to 1)

size

ValueRef : number, area of the mark in pixels

This is the total area of a symbol. For example, a value of 500 and a shape of 'circle' would result in circles with an area of 500 square pixels. Only used if type is 'symbol'.

shape

ValueRef : string, type of symbol to use

Possible values are 'circle' (default), 'square', 'cross', 'diamond', 'triangle-up', and 'triangle-down'. Only used if type is 'symbol'.

path

ValueRef : string, SVG path string

This would typically be used for maps and other things where the path is taken from the data.

inner_radius

ValueRef : number, inner radius of arc in pixels

Only used if type is 'arc'.

outer_radius

ValueRef : number, outer radius of the arc in pixels

Only used if type is 'arc'.

start_angle

ValueRef : number, start angle of the arc in radians

Only used if type is 'arc'.

end_angle

ValueRef : number, end angle of the arc in radians

Only used if type is 'arc'.

interpolate

ValueRef : string, line interpolation method to use

Possible values for area types are ‘linear’, 'step-before', 'step-after', 'basis', 'basis-open', 'cardinal', 'cardinal-open', 'monotone'. line types have all values for area as well as 'basis-closed', 'bundle', and 'cardinal-closed'.

Only used if type is 'area' or 'line'.

tension

ValueRef : number, tension used for interpolation

Only used if type is 'area' or 'line'.

url

ValueRef : string, url of image

Only used if type is 'image'.

align

ValueRef : string, horizontal alignment of mark

Possible values are 'left', 'right', and 'center'. Only used if type is 'image' or 'text'.

baseline

ValueRef : string, vertical alignment of mark

Possible values are 'top', 'middle', and 'bottom'. Only used if type is 'image' or 'text'.

text

ValueRef : string, text to display

Only used if type is 'text'.

dx

ValueRef : number, horizontal margin between text and anchor point in pixels

Ignored if align is 'center'. Only used if type is 'text'.

dy

ValueRef : number, vertical margin between text and anchor point in pixels

Ignored if baseline is 'middle'. Only used if type is 'text'.

font

ValueRef : string, typeface for text

Only used if type is 'text'.

font_size

ValueRef : number, font size in pixels

Only used if type is 'text'.

font_weight

ValueRef : string, font weight

Should be a valid SVG font weight. Only used if type is 'text'.

font_style

ValueRef : string, font style

Should be a valid SVG font style. Only used if type is 'text'.

Transforms¶

Field properties for Transform:

type

string: property name in which to store the computed transform value.

The valid transform types are as follows: array, copy, facet, filter, flatten, formula, sort, stats, unique, zip, force, geo, geopath, link, pie, stack, treemap, wordcloud

fields

list: Can take data references or object references

Only used if type is array or copy

from_

str: The name of the object to copy values from

Only used if type is copy

as_

list: The field names to copy the values to.

Can be used with the following type: copy unique zip

keys

list: Each key value corresponds to a single facet in the output.

Only used if type is facet

sort

string: Optional for sorting facet values

Only used if type is facet

test

string: A string containing a javascript filtering expression.

Ex: d.data.y >= 3

Only used if type is filter

field

string: Property name to store computed formula value.

Only used if type is formula or unique

See: https://github.com/trifacta/vega/wiki/Data-Transforms#-formula

expr

string: Javascript expression of a formula, referencing the data as d.

Only used if type is formula

See: https://github.com/trifacta/vega/wiki/Data-Transforms#-formula

by

str, list: a field or list of fields to sort. Can prepend with - to sort descending.

Only used if type is sort

value

str: Field for which to compute statistics.

Only used if type is stats

median

boolean: If true, median statistic will also be computed.

Only used if type is stats``

with_

string: Name of dataset to zip to current dataset

Only used if type is zip

key

string: Primary dataset field to match to secondary data

Only used if type is zip

with_key

string: Field in secondary dataset to match to primary

Only used if type is zip

links

string: Name of link (edge) data set.

To be used with force types

size

list: Dimensions of force layout

To be used with force types

iterations

int: Number of iterations to run force directed layout.

To be used with force types

charge

int or string: Strength of the charge each node exerts.

To be used with force types

link_distance

int or string: Determines lenght of the edges, in pixels.

To be used with force types

link_strength

int or string: Determines the tension of the edges.

To be used with force types

friction

int or float: Strength of friction force to stabilize layout

To be used with force types

theta

int or float: theta parameter for the Barnes-Hut algorithm.

To be used with force types

gravity

int or float: Strength of pseudo-gravity force

To be used with force types

alpha

int or float: “temperature” parameter to determine node position adjustment

To be used with force types

point

string: Data field determining the points at which to stack. When stacked vertically, these are the x-coords.

To be used with stack types

height

string: Data field determining thickness, or height of stacks.

To be used with stack types

offset

string: Baseline offset style. Must be one of the following:

zero, silhouette, wiggle, expand

To be used with stack types
order

str: The sort order for stack layers. Must be one of the following:

default, reverse, inside-out

To be used with stack types
